22. 
I submit that this procedure in the investigation 
of our records cannot be called scientific. 
Even in a letter the length of which may tax 
your patience, I have omitted much relevant criticism 
of the volume, but I have said enough to support the 
assertions that it contains both misrepresentation of 
the results of the Expedition and unjust reflections on 
<s>the<\s> its Officers. 
As regards the first I have found as an 
object the effort to adapt practical observations to a 
theoretical conception but in respect to the attack upon 
ourselves I am at a loss to suggest a motive. 
It is notorious that the preparations of 
the Antarctic Expedition were conducted amidst the 
stress of widely divergent opinions held by its advisers 
and it cannot be supposed that members of the Expedition 
failed to realize that its best interests were not served 
by the discussions which resulted. We had no share 
in these discussions and we bore the brunt of their effect 
on the organization and equipment of the Expedition; 
yet in no case has any one of us drawn attention to these 
drawbacks or sought to attribute failure to the blunders 
and shortcomings in the instructions or in the Instrumental 
Equipment provided for our use. 
It has been left to Dr Shaw to revive without 
useful purpose and under the title 'Miscarriage of 
<u>Instructions'<\u>
